identificationModule.briefTitle: Pharyngeal Electrical Stimulation for the Treatment of Post-extubation Dysphagia in Acute Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Randomised Controlled Trial of Pharyngeal Electrical Stimulation for the Treatment of Post-extubation Dysphagia in Acute Stroke Patients

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether pharyngeal electrical stimulation in addition to standard care can enhance swallowing recovery in severely dysphagic stroke patients post extubation compared to sham treatment plus standard care.

armGroups.label: Pharyngeal electrical stimulation
armGroups.description: Pharyngeal electrical stimulation once daily for 10 minutes on three consecutive days.

armGroups.label: Sham stimulation
armGroups.description: Sham stimulation once daily for 10 minutes on three consecutive days.

interventions.name: Phagenyx-Catheter, Phagenesis Limited, UK.
interventions.description: Pharyngeal electrical stimulation via an intraluminal catheter (Phagenesis Ltd.) once daily for 10 minutes on three consecutive days. The intensity of the electrical stimulation is determined following the calculation of suitable sensory threshold, tailored to the individual patients. After determining the optimal stimulation intensity, 10 minutes of stimulation are delivered.

interventions.name: Sham stimulation
interventions.description: The intraluminal catheter (Phagenesis Ltd.) for pharyngeal electrical stimulation is placed. In the sham group the optimisation procedure was imitated as closely as possible to mitigate any bias or effect of time spent interacting with the patient during PES, but no current was applied. After this procedure 10 min of sham stimulation were delivered.

primaryOutcomes.description: Need for reintubation within 120 hours from extubation
Incidence of aspiration pneumonia within 120 hours from extubation

secondaryOutcomes.description: Length of stay on the intensive care unit
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of stay on the intensive care unit, an expected average of 3 weeks

secondaryOutcomes.description: Time span from extubation until consumption of an completely oral diet is safely possible
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 4 weeks

secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of participants needing percutaneous endogastric tube placement due to persistent severe dysphagia
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 5 weeks.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Salient semiquantitative parameters of swallowing function (leaking, penetration, aspiration, residues, delayed triggering of swallow reflex) as assessed by a standardized fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation protocol after three days of treatment

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

- severe dysphagia post extubation due to acute stroke

Exclusion Criteria:

* preexisting dysphagia
* comorbidities that can possibly cause dysphagia
* psychiatric comorbidities
* pacemaker or other implanted electronic devices
